user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA256_update:
```c
void
MHD_SHA256_update (struct Sha256Ctx *ctx,
                   const uint8_t *data,
                   size_t length)
{
  unsigned bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in buffer */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned) (ctx->count & (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned bytes_left = SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      sha256_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    sha256_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_SHA256_update:
#define SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE_BITS/8)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in MHD_SHA256_update are invariant and therefore none require further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.

Reasons (per controlling statement in the function):
- mhd_assert((data != NULL) || (length == 0)): uses the parameter data and length (runtime values); not an invariant.
- #ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE / if (0 == length) return;: the condition depends on the parameter length; it is not a compile-time invariant.
- bytes_have = (unsigned) (ctx->count & (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE - 1)); if (0 != bytes_have) { ... }: bytes_have is computed from ctx->count (a context field) and may vary at runtime; the controlling expression is not invariant.
- if (length >= bytes_left): depends on the runtime parameter length and the computed bytes_left; not invariant.
- while (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE <= length): although SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE is a compile-time constant, the right-hand operand length is modified inside the loop (length -= SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE), so the controlling expression is variant across iterations and not invariant.
- if (0 != length): depends on the runtime-modified length; not invariant.

No do-while loops or intentionally infinite invariant-controlled loops are present; the exceptions cited for Rule 14.3 do not apply. Therefore there are no suspicious invariant controlling expressions to report.
